Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Thermal control of avidity for separation of biologicals

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511227
Rao
North Carolina State U

Affinity chromatography exploits the highly specific interaction between molecules or ligands immobilized on a surface and the target species of interest. In the proposed work affinity adsorbents will be generated with the proposed molecules or ligands for both small and large scale separations using the same synthesis scheme. These affinity adsorbents are expected to be robust and amenable to multiple re-uses after sterilization. Yet, it is expected that production of adsorbents for single-use applications with high value biologicals will still be cost-effective. Collaboration with a North Carolina State-based company will be undertaken to explore the development of commercial membrane-based separation systems for complex biologicals.

To identify temperature-sensitive affinity ligands, a peptide-based scaffold that changes conformation in response to changes in temperature will be evaluated. Affinity ligands for two model targets will be generated: CD117, which is expressed on hematopoietic stem cells, and TOM22, a mitochondrial protein. Subsequently, the effectiveness of these ligands will be evaluated in the context of cell and mitochondrial separation. Accordingly, combinatorial libraries of peptides will be screened to identify peptides binders for the model targets. Thermo-responsive ligands will also be constructed using the peptides generated. Subsequently, the effect of temperature on the binding affinity of these ligands will be evaluated. Finally, the use of magnetic beads functionalized with the selected ligands will be evaluated in the context of separation of CD117+ cells and mitochondria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to develop thermally responsive affinity ligands based on cyclic peptides for separation of biologicals such as cells, viruses, and organelles. Towards this end, we have developed three technologies for generation and quantitative characterization of cyclic peptide binders using the combinatorial library screening platforms mRNA display and yeast surface display. In mRNA display, a peptide or protein is linked to its coding sequence through a puromycin linker during an in vitro translation procedure. In yeast surface display, peptides or proteins are expressed as cell surface fusions to yeast cells. Peptides or proteins with desired properties are selected from a library of nucleic acid-peptide hybrids or yeast surface fusions and identified by DNA sequencing.

First, we developed two approaches to efficiently magnetize yeast cells and screen mRNA display libraries of peptides: (1) yeast cells expressing the target protein as cell surface fusions were magnetized by physical adsorption of iron oxide nanoparticles. (2) Yeast cells were magnetized by co-expressing an engineered protein that binds iron oxide on the cell surface along with the target protein of interest. A key challenge in obtaining binders to membrane proteins associated with biologicals is often obtaining recombinant purified versions of the target protein. We showed that cyclic peptides could be isolated from mRNA display libraries using magnetized yeast cells displaying the target protein.

Second, we developed methods to isolate protein and cyclic peptide binders to yeast displayed protein targets using yeast displayed peptide libraries and target proteins displayed on magnetized yeast cells. Notably, we demonstrated combinatorial libraries of chemically cyclized cyclic peptides could be constructed using the yeast display platform.

Third, we developed a platform for quantitative analysis of protein-protein (or protein-peptide) interactions called quantitative yeast-yeast two hybrid (qYY2H). Quantifying the binding affinity of protein-protein interactions is important for elucidating connections within biochemical signaling pathways, as well as characterization of binding proteins and peptides isolated from combinatorial libraries. qYY2H not only enables discovery of specific protein-protein interactions, but also efficient, quantitative estimation of their binding affinities (KD). Further, qYY2H could also quantitatively evaluate bindinginteractions mediated by post-translational modifications on the bait protein.

Overall, our research resulted in six publications and one book chapter that acknowledge support from this grant. We anticipate that our findings will have a significant impact in the discipline of molecular engineering.

We have also integrated our research activities with a broader plan for education and K-12 outreach. Two graduate and three undergraduate students were involved in implementation of this project. The PI has included concepts pertaining to mRNA display and combinatorial library screening in a course taught to undergraduate students in their senior year, in the department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering. Additionally, a graduate student involved with this project has participated in a number of outreach activities such as coaching a Science Olympiad team for an elementary school, and organizing events for middle school and high school aged girls to encourage participation in STEM.
